description.p: June 27 - Aug 30, 2009: On the road with my Honda Shadow 750, riding alongside my hubby and his BMW R1150GS. Then to England, Jersey and France. Back to Nanaimo through the USA on above-mentionned bikes. Well, this is the plan at least...

item.title: turbulent tummy
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
turbulent tummy
Markham, Canada
Markham, Canada

We arrived in Toronto despite the tornado and lightening & thunder storm. What a landing!

Was I ever glad to be off that plane! I can't remember the last time i was ever sick but it is not pleasant.

All i want is a bed now. Goodnight!

item.title: a family affair
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
a family affair
Scarborough, Canada
Scarborough, Canada

A family bbq with all the grandchildren there, what a treat for
Grandma! Being the oldest grandchild, I felt a bit old - and vertically
challenged, but there you have it!

item.title: in the saddle again and loving it
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.wp:post_name: in the saddle again and loving it
item.content:encoded:
in the saddle again and loving it
Durand, MI
Durand, MI

We're heading west to go home after a fantastic summer.

It feels so right to be back on my bike again, it's like we never parted.

Was on the road by noon. A good, albeit wet, ride today. A bit of delay at the Sarnia/Port Huron border for Matt to renew his visa waiver form but no complaints.

It will be interesting to compare the journey back through the US. Already i notice the incessant Golden Arches that are at every single junction.

Aiming to be back in Nanaimo by September 1st but we'll see how things develop and how the roads are.

This journey is to be savoured.

item.title: familiar feeling
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
familiar feeling
Madison, WI
Madison, WI

We rode for 630km today .... a bit more really because we did a few detours trying to find a place for a deep-pan pizza lunch (very difficult since most places are closed on Sundays, which we didn't know - or expect!) and at around the 200 km mark on my odometer, we found
ourselves on the Chicago Sky route (this narrow highway 'bridge' with no shoulder) and so we had to turn off quickly to try and find any gas station or risk me running into a dry tank. We ended up detouring around some local airport in an industrial area - a very 'interesting' insight into Chicago's suburbs. But at least we found a petrol station in the end.

Going through Chicago itself was fantastic. The skyline is beautiful, and although we got stuck in brutal traffic for over an hour (going at about 10km/hr) this will probably be the only
major city we actually ride through. But we were glad to be out of the traffic jam...my left hand was starting to ache from controlling the clutch at low speed. Good practice indeed! At one point we just turned off our engines and pushed our bikes along slowly.

We've gone through Michigan, Indiana, Illinois, and now we're in Madison, Wisconsin. There aren't any 'border crossings' as such and sometimes not even a sign to tell you you're in another state. It all merges and flows into one another. All names to me before this trip, but I'm
slowly piecing together the gigantic puzzle of this country. I find it interesting to see all the various license plates and notice where they're coming from. The furthest so far iIve seen is Colorado and New York. No BC plates yet!

At around 6pm (we crossed a time zone after having passed Chicago, so we gained another hour!) we stopped for dinner just before Rockford. Michigan. We shared the popular and
delicious Chicago beef sandwich and I have to admit i caved and ordered a huge plate of msg-filled Chinese food from 'Panda Express' :)

We were still pretty energetic so we decided to ride for another couple of hours.... we hit a massive traffic jam about 30 kms into it and were stuck for quite a while. More clutch-control exercises for me!! There was a major car crash on the other side but traffic did eventually
move.... the poor people trying to get back into Chicago after a weekend must've been waiting for hours! I noticed that the standstill on that side went on for more than 10kms!

Today our aim is to get to Sioux Falls, South Dakota. The next day we should be in Rapid
City (the badlands!) where we'll pass by Mount Rushmore...

Hopefully we'll have enough time to take it slowly and meander through Yellowstone National Park, definitely something I've been looking forward to since we started.

We're staying America's Best Value Inn and value it is. For $44 USD we get a king-size bed, free wifi, cable tv, an outdoor pool, and the breakfast - phenomenal! There are waffle makers that you can help yourself to, scrambled eggs, potatoes, sausages, cereal, bagels, pastries and American style grits! They sure do value their food here, especially in quantity!

item.title: guardian angel
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
guardian angel
Albert Lea, MN
Albert Lea, MN

Our first day with sunshine, even at 10am (after excellent free
breakfast included in our $44 room) it was baking hot but cooler as we
got moving. Got some good miles done, then lunch at Subway just after
we crossed the Mississippsiiisiiispiii River (sp?).

Then things
got worse, Bonnie got a bit of turbulent tummy so she overtook me and
directed us off the Interstate just south of Rochester. Eventually we
found a gas station where she pulled up at the pump then rushed to find
a toilet. While she was in there I filled the bikes.

She got
back, we were about to set off then I realised we were at a diesel
pump! Bonnie had just pulled up at the first pump so she could run to
the toilet and I hadn't checked what it was, we'll learn to double
check, but didn't we say that when we did exactly the same thing in
France a year ago???

Luckily we hadn't started the engines and
just as we were walking the bikes to the parking lot Byron rode up on
his antique BMW. He is the area representative for BMW owners of
America and today he was our samaritan and saviour. 4 hours later both
tanks were drained and although he offered to put up his old tent and
let us sleep in his back yard we managed to get another 100kms down the
road and stayed the night in Albert Lea.

Sleepy Minnesota town
and the lady at the motel check in desk told us not to worry about
vandalism and that we should park next to the white Toyota, just under
the streetlamp so it would be visible from the motel reception area. I
went outside to tell Bonnie then a man with a
hammer chased a woman
out of the hotel restaurant, she got into the white Toyota and he
started screaming at her and attacking the Toyota with a hammer. She
drove off and within seconds police cars had converged and arrested the
hammer man.

Enough drama for the day, we had a sandwich and
salad and beer at the hotel restaurant, then to bed. Forecast of some
thunder showers tomorrow but as long as we get less drama than today I
won't be complaining!

Matt (filling in as blogger while Bonnie rests)

item.title: redeemed
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
redeemed
Wall, SD
Wall, SD

Today:
-started off with some intense spurts of rain
-sunshine and big open skies followed
-miles and miles of corn fields dotted with wind turbines
-saw a plane dusting sunflower fields, very very cool
-long straight empty roads, wishing for twisty roads
-passed many billboards.. getting sick of them but can't help reading them!
-Many advertise the towns and attractions ahead. If you've passed the exit
junction, the next billboard will scream "STOP! You've just missed
XXXXX, turn off at next exit"
-Many messages of faith and Christianity. Ie: "There are many ways to go to hell but only one way to heaven - Jesus"
-Into the Badlands National Park, Matt tipped his bike over at entrance while
trying to read the signs.... adrenalin pumping, he yanks the bike
upright just as i ran over. No visible damage.
-Incredible scenery at Badlands
-the twisty roads were excellent!!
-Had yummy 'Indian Taco' at local family diner in Wall. It's fried dough
bread (bannock) topped with refried beans, ground beef, salad and
cheese.

Summary:
Successful riding day! 771 kms exact! Redeemed ourselves after yesterday's incident. On schedule once more.

item.title: the perfect day
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
the perfect day
Ten Sleep, WY
Ten Sleep, WY

627 km of blissful riding. Probably the most enjoyable riding day I've ever had in my short riding career.

We've gone through some interesting and unique town names, many derived from
the First Nations who were here first and created legends about the
land. Some names include: Kalamazoo,....and others i will post later

After riding on the I-90 for some time now, we decided to take a side route
to get to Yellowstone National Park. By chance, we turned west after
Buffalo and the scenery just got more and more dramatic. It was
absolutely stunning, no other words to describe it. You know how some
things can look/hear/taste/feel so incredible that you would actually
tear up? Well, this was one of those moments.

I'm going to cheat and copy/paste what the Ten Sleep website has wrote about on how its name was derived:

"Nestled in the base of the Big Horn Mountains in the Nowood Valley, 26 miles
east of Worland on US Highway 16, Ten Sleep long ago staked its claim
to a share of Wyoming’s and Washakie County’s colored history. Ten
Sleep received its name because of the method of measuring
distance that was used by Indians at one time.

There was once a large Sioux Indian camp on the banks of the Platte River,
and there was another large Indian camp on the Clark's Fork River to
the North, near present-day Bridger, Montana. These camps
were important to Indians and settlers due to the trails leading to

and from them in all directions across the West. According to the
reckoning of the Indians, it was twenty "sleeps," or nights, between
the two camps.

It took ten "sleeps" to get halfway between them. This became the
location of the present town of Ten Sleep."

With a population of 350 (estimated) it is a sleepy little Western town but
full of natural glory and splendor. And with delicious oven-baked pizza
too in the town's only pizzeria!

item.title: wooooosh!!!!!!!
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
wooooosh!!!!!!!
West Yellowstone, MT
West Yellowstone, MT

Old Faithful didn't disappoint.

Saw a beautiful bison at sunset.

Good riding but the traffic made it more exhausting than necessary. Apparently Yellowstone National Park gets 30,000+ visitors PER DAY!

More to come later... just wanted to post pics now while i have high-speed connection.

item.title: a must see!
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
a must see!
Columbia Falls, MT
Columbia Falls, MT

Glacier National Park is fantastic. The highway, named "Into The Sun Highway" (exactly what we were doing!), hugs the mountainside, dips into valleys and brings you up through glorious passes. It's like a 50 km scenic roller coaster ride. Wheeeee!

item.title: Canadian homecoming
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.content:encoded:
Canadian homecoming
Grand Forks, Canada
Grand Forks, Canada

Another beautiful ride in the Rockies. Everything is just so green!

And fantastic twisty roads going up and down and around mountain bends...
there were a few times where my poor bike just couldn't catch up to
Matt's, throttle open and all! Going around a sharp right hand corner
at one point my right foot peg skimmed the ground.. it shook me up a
bit but no damage done.

We crossed back into Canada from the Idaho border. It feels good to be back on Canadian soil.

We immediately stopped at a local cafe in Creston for a good smoothie and
homemade chilli. For some reason, I'm feeling much safer and relaxed
being back in BC.

We checked into this fantastic motel in quaint Grand Forks and then walked next door for a delicious Russian meal. The borscht and perogies were like something i've never tasted before! What a welcome change from Subway lunches and burgers and fries!

523 km to go until home! Can't wait to be riding up to our apartment, I've
imagined this for so long. Last stretch, we'll be sure to make it safe.

item.title: the green green grass of home
item.dc:creator: bonthorn
item.wp:post_name: the green green grass of home
item.content:encoded:
the green green grass of home
Nanaimo, Canada
Nanaimo, Canada

We made it on the ferry - with seconds to spare! But for some reason,
just based on how everything worked out on this trip, we both knew we
would make the ferry, even when all the factors seemed stacked against
us. And even if we didn’t, the next one was only 2 hours later.
But we made it, and we are excited to be home in a couple of hours!

Some
might look at my Honda Shadow 750 and think it was only a piece of
complicated machinery put together in a factory. But I have come to
love and care for this bike like it were an extension of myself. And so
it's only right that I give it the proper thanks it deserves....


Dear Beloved Bike,

Our
journey is coming to an end. I am sitting here eating sushi on the
ferry deck while you’re down below on the vehicle deck. We are minutes
away from Nanaimo.

It has been a tremendous journey
this summer, seeing parts of Canada and the USA, all on your reliable
two wheels. You never let me down and kept me safe every second of the
way, during the torrential downpours, the gravel tracks, the miles of
construction and detours, the starless nights, the thick forest roads
and the great open plains. You gave every ounce of energy to this
journey, you responded to every request of mine and you never gave up.

I’m
sorry about the diesel in your tank; that incident taught us to be more
vigilant when selecting your ‘drink of choice’. I’m just glad you
weren’t further damaged.

I was most proud when my family got to
see (and ride!) you for the first time. I also enjoyed all the random
conversations that were started in various gas stations around the
continent, all because of you!

It will probably be a
while before we embark on another long-distance road trip. But we’ll
still cruise around town and on do some island daytrips. There’s no way
I want to ever stop riding; you have given me the experience and the
memories that have made me a lifelong rider. And a safe one too. What
more could I ask for?

Thank you for this golden opportunity to have this roadtrip of a lifetime. Those 10529.5 kms won't be forgotten anytime soon!


Bon xoxo
